text: the American nuclear industry responded
today to all this worry about what's
going on in Japan and they came out
swinging pretty hard they said yes we
will take a good look at what happened
over there when we know what happened
but so far they said our Japanese
colleagues haven't told us a whole lot
they're busy fighting fires literally
but they said that in general American
plants are better setup than the
Japanese plants for example one of the
problems of the Japanese plants is they
had diesel fuel to run emergency
generators that tsunami came in and
swept away the diesel fuel at American
plants the tanks with the diesel fuel
are generally underground there are
relicensing procedures going on for some
older plants including some that are
quite similar to the Japanese design but
the American industry argues well those
license extension proceedings refer to
aging are the concrete and steel
structures of the cables as good as they
were when they were new they don't refer
to was the design any good in the first
place the other thing that's going on is
there are four reactors under
construction two in Georgia to in South
Carolina neither one anywhere near the
coast the company in Georgia Southern
Company came out today and said we
really sympathize with the troubles of
the Japanese and we're going to build
this plant on time on schedule
